newsitem.title: UK: London precious metals drift lower in slow PM.
newsitem.headline: London precious metals drift lower in slow PM.

text.p: Precious metals prices eased back on Wednesday afternoon in the absence of follow-through buying since silver rallied earlier in the week, dealers said.
Bullion fixed lower at $386.80 an ounce, compared to $387.45 in the morning and $387.10 on Tuesday afternoon.
Bids were quoted so far between $387.85 and $386.50.
"We saw gold firm up a bit on back of the Monday rally in silver, but everyone is looking for follow through. There's a danger it could drift back to where it started," a dealer said.
Comex December gold was down $0.70 at $392.20 compared to Tuesday's New York close.
Analysts said gold needed to get past resistance at $390 to make further gains, although producer selling at that level was expected to make progress difficult.
"(Gold) may this week re-try $388-$390. There's resistance there but maybe not as much as people think. We've already been there recently," one dealer said.
Silver, considered the leader the complex since soaring in New York on chart-driven buying, was still consolidating its gains in a narrow range for the second day running.
It was indicated was a shade lower at $5.19/$5.21, down three cents from Tuesday's London close.
"The market is very slow. Everyone's waiting for some reason to do something," a dealer said. Some said they were looking for silver to go as high as $5.30, possibly this week.
But silver may need gold's support to successfully pierce key resistance around $5.25, analysts said.
In that case, upside targets would be at $5.30, then $5.42, levels at which layers of selling were likely to emerge.
Otherwise, silver should find support at previous resistance around $5.15-$5.16, the level which had largely capped its range in recent weeks.
Bids were quoted so far between $5.23 and $5.18.
Platinum also eased a bit to $398.50/$399.50, down $0.80 from Monday's London close, amid a lack of interest.

Its sister metal palladium, which has edged up slightly since hitting 2-1/2 year earlier this week, was indicated at $125.00/$126.00, down $0.10. But its potential for further gains was also hampered by the summer lull.
"Palladium has bounced off lows and found its bottom, so now people are bargain hunting and covering shorts. But there's no sign of an influx of industrial buying yet," a dealer said.
